channel.title: Bloomberg Economics

item.title: German Investor Confidence Jumps as Fiscal Boost Outweighs Trade
item.description: Investor confidence in Germany’s economy improved more than anticipated as a forthcoming surge in public spending outweighs fears over looming US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: Sweden’s Faltering Growth May Force Another Rate Cut
item.description: The Riksbank may be about to restart a cycle of interest-rate-cutting that officials had signaled to be over as recently as March.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas, Charlie Duxbury

item.title: Trump’s Latest Attack on the Fed Zooms In on Surging Debt Costs
item.description: Donald Trump is putting new spin on his months-long call for the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates: It’s important for bringing down the cost of government debt.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump, Starmer Agree to Implement Tariff-Cutting Trade Deal
item.description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer reached an agreement with US President Donald Trump to implement some main elements of the trade deal announced last month to lower US tariffs on key British exports and raise UK quotas on certain American agricultural products.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump meets with Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer on the sidelines of the G7 Summit in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: BOJ to Slow Bond Market Withdrawal After Standing Pat on Rates
item.description: The Bank of Japan unveiled a plan to step back from the bond market at a slower pace from next year to ensure market stability while sticking to a path of normalization that includes the possibility of more rate hikes.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka, Sumio Ito

item.title: ECB Amends Bank Capital Reviews to Reflect Extreme Weather Risks
item.description: The European Central Bank is embedding climate risk into regular reviews of how well banks can absorb losses, marking a new chapter in its supervisory approach.
item.dc:creator: Frances Schwartzkopff

media:content.media:description: Homes beside a riverbed destroyed after flash floods in Chiva, Spain in 2024.

item.title: Chile Set to Hold Key Rate, Hint at Future Cuts: Decision Guide
item.description: Chile’s central bank will likely hold its key interest rate steady Tuesday, while signaling plans to resume monetary easing as global headwinds crimp growth and local inflation slows toward target.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

item.title: ECB Has Found ‘Equilibrium’ on Rates, Prices, Growth, Stournaras Says
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Yannis Stournaras says it seems the euro area has reached an equilibrium when it comes to inflation, banking-sector developments and economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas

item.title: Modi Misses Chance to Push for US Trade Deal as Trump Leaves G-7
item.description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi had no opportunity to push for a US trade deal with Donald Trump after the American president left the Group of Seven leaders’ summit early, a potential setback for New Delhi as recent tariff negotiations hit hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Sudhi Ranjan Sen

media:content.media:description: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, center, arrives at Calgary Airport on June 16. Photographer: Dave Chidley/Getty Images

item.title: RBI Governor Seeks to Clear Up Market Confusion on Rate Outlook
item.description: India’s central bank may have space for further policy easing if inflation undershoots its projections, said Governor Sanjay Malhotra, seeking to address market confusion sparked by his earlier remarks that the authority has limited room for easing.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar, Bhaskar Dutta, Anup Roy

media:content.media:description: Sanjay Malhotra

item.title: Irish State Exits AIB, Putting Bank Into Private Ownership
item.description: The Irish state has disposed of the remainder of its shareholding in AIB Group plc, putting the bank into private ownership.
item.dc:creator: Olivia Fletcher

media:content.media:description: An Allied Irish Banks branch in Dublin.

item.title: Thailand Plans Finance Industry Tax Cuts to Build Frontier Hub
item.description: Thailand is planning to lower taxes and cut red tape to help it become a financial hub for investors doing business regionally, especially in frontier markets like Cambodia, Laos and Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paopoom Rojanasakul Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Weighs Reversing Non-Dom Inheritance Tax Changes, FT Says
item.description: Rachel Reeves is considering reversing a decision to charge inheritance tax on the overseas assets of non-doms, according to the Financial Times.
item.dc:creator: Leonard Kehnscherper

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves, UK chancellor of the exchequer, outside 11 Downing Street ahead of the presentation of the spending review in London, UK, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Reeves will defend her fiscal choices and trumpet billions of pounds of infrastructure investment in the UK spending review on Wednesday, as Keir Starmer's government seeks to regain momentum after a faltering first year in power. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: More Central Banks Than Ever Plan to Build Up Their Gold Hoards
item.description: A record share of the world’s central banks plans to accumulate more gold over the next 12 months, drawn by bullion’s performance during times of crisis and protection against inflation.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

item.title: Global Euro Moment Needs Decisive Action, ECB’s Lagarde Says
item.description: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde called on policymakers to seize the moment and increase the euro’s global profile as Donald Trump’s policies undermines confidence in the US dollar.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. The ECB lowered interest rates for the eighth time in a year after inflation dipped beneath 2% and the economy suffered repeated blows from US tariffs. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Bank of England’s Finances Squeezed in Wake of Bernanke Reforms
item.description: For centuries the Bank of England has been the guardian of Britain’s financial health. Now the central bank is facing a budget crunch of its own as it repairs dilapidated IT infrastructure, ramps up hiring and overhauls the way it makes forecasts in response to Ben Bernanke’s review.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick

item.title: Tourism Dip Fuels Worst Stock Drop in Asia at Thai Airport Firm
item.description: Thailand’s post-Covid flood of tourists has turned into more of a trickle, adding to concerns for Airports of Thailand Pcl as it grapples with shrinking duty-free sales without a full-time chief executive officer.
item.dc:creator: Anuchit Nguyen

media:content.media:description: Chinese travelers have turned away from the Southeast Asian nation after the viral kidnapping of a Chinese actor in January stoked worries about security. Photographer: NurPhoto/NurPhoto

item.title: China Housing Demand to Stay at 75% Below Peak, Goldman Says
item.description: China’s demand for new homes in cities is expected to stay at 75% below its 2017 peak in the coming years due to a shrinking population and expectations of price declines that have been hurting investment interest, according to Goldman Sachs Group Inc.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu

item.title: Brazil Congress Threatens to Deal Fresh Blow to Lula Fiscal Plan
item.description: President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva’s efforts to shore up Brazil’s budget are on the brink of another setback after Congress advanced a push to block tax increases on some financial transactions from taking effect.
item.dc:creator: Simone Iglesias, Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Carney Says Canada and US Aiming For Trade Deal Within 30 Days
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada and the US are aiming to strike a trade deal within a month, a goal set during a meeting with US President Donald Trump at the Group of Seven summit.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaks during a meeting with US President Donald Trump on the sidelines of the G7 Summit, in Kananaskis, Canada, on June 16. Photographer: Mark Schiefelbein/AP Photo

item.title: Wary of Global Tensions, Zimbabwe Holds Interest Rates at 35%
item.description: Zimbabwe, wary of a rise in global tensions, resolved to leave its bank policy rate unchanged at 35%, according to John Mushayavanhu, the central bank governor.
item.dc:creator: Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: John Mushayavanhu, governor of Zimbabwe’s central bank

item.title: Senate Deadlocked on SALT, With Draft Bill Showing Current $10,000 Cap
item.description: The Senate’s version of President Donald Trump’s tax bill calls for a $10,000 cap on the state and local tax deduction — a placeholder figure as Republicans remain divided over the valuable tax break.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune

item.title: Hungary Sells $4 Billion in Bonds to Fund Orban’s Budget Gap
item.description: Hungary sold $4 billion in a three-part dollar debt deal on Monday after the government decided to boost overseas borrowing to fund its budget.
item.dc:creator: Andras Gergely

media:content.media:description: Viktor Orban, Hungary's prime minister, looks on during a news conference in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, Feb. 2, 2017. Russia's President Vladimir Putin will step up efforts to weaken support for economic sanctions against Russia in his first visit to the European Union since Donald Trump became U.S. president with a pledge to improve relations with the Kremlin leader.

item.title: G-7 Works to Secure Critical Minerals in Face of China Curbs
item.description: The Group of Seven leading economies are working to shore up supplies of critical minerals as they seek to move away from reliance on China for materials used in everything from mobile phones to wind turbines.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero

media:content.media:description: Bags of rare earth concentrates sit for transport at the Mountain Pass mine in Mountain Pass, California.

item.title: Trump to Leave G-7 Tonight Due to Middle East Crisis

media:content.media:description: Attendees at the G7 Media Centre before the G7 Leaders' Summit in Banff, Alberta, on June 15. Photographer: Gavin John/Bloomberg

item.title: Nigeria’s Annual Inflation Rate Slows for Second Month in a Row
item.description: Nigeria’s annual inflation rate cooled for a second straight month, giving policymakers a clearer picture of price trends after a data revamp in January clouded the outlook.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo

media:content.media:description: Taxi vans parked near high-rise commercial office buildings in the Central Business District (CBD) of Lagos, Nigeria, on Monday, Aug. 14, 2023. Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has declared a state of emergency to counter the rising cost of living and in early August announced a 500 billion naira package of measures to improve food supply, ease transportation costs and boost manufacturing.

item.title: Canada Home Sales Up for First Time in Six Months on Trade Hopes
item.description: Home sales in Canada rose for the first time in six months in May as buyers’ confidence strengthened amid a de-escalation of trade tensions with the US.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh, Ari Altstedter

media:content.media:description: Downtown Toronto.

item.title: SNB Set to Cut to Zero But Shirk From Negative Rate for Now
item.description: The Swiss National Bank will probably lower its interest rate to zero this week and stay there for some time, a Bloomberg survey of economists showed, just as new government forecasts pointed to persistently slow inflation.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Zoe Schneeweiss, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: New York Factory Activity Contracts While Outlook Improves
item.description: New York state factory activity shrank in June by more than projected as orders and shipments contracted, though expectations improved.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: An employee wearing a cleanroom suit performs maintenance inside a semiconductor manufacturing facility in Malta, New York.

item.title: Brazil 2025 Inflation Forecasts Fall Ahead of Key Rate Decision
item.description: Brazil’s 2025 year-end inflation expectations dropped for third straight week, just before central bankers meet to decide whether or not to extend their cycle of interest rate hikes.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati

media:content.media:description: Shoppers browse a clothing stand at the Setor Comercial Sul in Brasilia.
